.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. .NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode

.NET Core TipStruggling with spam in your lead or contact forms, even with CAPTCHA in place? Hereâ€™s a quick tip to help reduce unwanted submissions effectively.Dealing with spam in your lead or contact forms can be incredibly frustrating. But don't worry, there's a solution!Using .NET Core 8.0 MVC, I'll show you how to effectively block spam submissions. The logic applies to any technology, so you can adapt it to your needs.Here's a typical contact/lead form:<form asp-action="contact" asp-controller="home" method="post"> <input class="form-control" type="text" maxlength="255" asp-for="FullName" placeholder="Your Name" required> <input class="form-control" type="email" maxlength="255" asp-for="Email" placeholder="Your Mail" required> <input class="form-control" type="text" pattern="^[0-9]*$" maxlength="15" asp-for="Phone" placeholder="Your Phone with country code"> <textarea class="form-control" asp-for="Message" cols="40" rows="5" maxlength="1000" placeholder="Your Message" required></textarea></form>Spammers use automated scripts to find and submit these forms, flooding your inbox with spam. To fight this, we will add a hidden input field to form:<input class="additional-note" type="text" style="display:none;">When the form is submitted, we check if this hidden field is empty. If it is, the submission is likely from a human. If not, it's probably spam.Here's the controller logic:[HttpPost("contact")][ValidateReCaptcha]public async Task<IActionResult> Contact(LeadModel model){ if (!ModelState.IsValid) return View(); try { bool result = await _contactService.SaveLead(model); TempData["success"] = result ? "We have received your request, we will get back to you shortly!" : "Sorry! We are not able to save your request."; return RedirectToAction("contact", "home"); } catch (Exception ex) { TempData["fail"] = "Sorry! Something went wrong to save your request."; _logger.LogError(ex, $"An error occurred to save lead - {Helper.Dump(model)}"); } return View();}And the business logic service:public async Task<bool> SaveLead(LeadModel? leadModel){ if (leadModel == null || !string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace(leadModel.RepeatLead)) return false; var lead = _mapper.Map<Lead?>(leadModel); return await _contactRepository.SaveLead(lead);}Implement this simple trick to keep your forms spam-free and ensure you only get genuine leads. ğŸš€ğŸ’¬ What do you think of this approach? Have you tried something similar? Share your thoughts in the comments below! And don't forget to share this post with your friends and colleagues who might find it useful. Let's help each other keep our forms spam-free! ğŸ’ªhashtag#spamprevention hashtag#dotetcore hashtag#leadform hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#leadgeneration hashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp

â€œWhy FCL is Like a Swiss Army Knife for Developers!â€ğŸ¤·Imagine this:Youâ€™re on a solo trip. You carry one thing in your bag â€” a Swiss Army Knife.Why?Because it has everything â€” scissors, a knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, and more.Thatâ€™s exactly what FCL is for a .NET developer.A one-stop toolbox that helps you build your app without reinventing the wheel every time.What is FCL (Framework Class Library)?Itâ€™s a collection of ready-made classes, interfaces, and value types that provide core functionalities like: â€¢	Reading files â€¢	Working with databases â€¢	Displaying data on screen â€¢	Encrypting information â€¢	Sending messages & moreğŸ˜‡Why should you care?Because without FCL, youâ€™d be writing 100s of lines of code just to read a text file or make an API call.Real-Life Analogy:Need to fix your glasses?Grab the mini screwdriver from your Swiss knife â€” no need to carry a full toolbox.Need to parse a JSON in .NET?Use System.Text.Json from FCL â€” no need to write your own parser.So, next time you open Visual Studio, remember:FCL is your Swiss Army Knife â€” making your developer journey lighter, faster, and smarter!Have you discovered any hidden gem in FCL that made your day easier?Drop it in the comments!hashtag#DotNet hashtag#FullStackDeveloper hashtag#FCL hashtag#CodingSimplified hashtag#DevLife hashtag#CleanCode
